In the rabbits/lichen example, it is unclear what you are saying. The 1-5 fungal/yeast partner's and the 1-2 algal/cyanobacteria partner's spores can all be dispersed by wind. So lichens can get to new islands faster than rabbits can. But individual rabbits can move further in their lives than individual lichens. Which were you saying?

Regarding hashes being unique - that is total nonsense. Take AES-256. Since you can feed it every file of 256 bits (would take longer than the universe has existed) and bigger files (all files) as well, by the pigeon-hole-principle, anyone can see that AES-256 hash MUST have collisions. The most beloved new data-structure in modern computer programming languages is the dictionary/hash. All of the implementations I know of, the end pointer of a hash leads to a linked-list (almost always consisting of one element). When there is a collision (rarely), the infrastructure reads through the (extremely short) linked-list and adds an element to the end.
... (i.e. not a new paragraph)
There are ways to create a perfect hash - see https://www.gnu.org/software/gperf/
But they are far too expensive to setup beforehand that they are seldom used in the real world, and never for your examples.

As long as the hash is smaller than what is being hashed, the thing being hashed can be more than one thing.

this is kind of nitpicky, but computers can't understand hashes, computers can't understand anything because it's their programmers that do the understanding. by design, cryptographic hashes are difficult (hopefully impossible) to understand, precisely so that comparing them is basically all you're supposed to be able to do with them. there are also hashes like those designed for razor (spam detection tool, so intended for use on adverserial inputs) and musicbrainz which are designed to have partial collisions for related inputs. in other words not only equality is useful, but partial collisions can be interpreted as degrees of similarity based on an understanding of the problem domain (detecting mass mail even when individual emails are still unique, or searching for missing tags even when using lossily compressed audio data)

Hashing functions may or may not produce unique results. They are not guaranteed unique.

Hashing is more or less equatable to "binning". If you have more balls (input combinations) than bins (unique output results), then some bins are guaranteed to have more than one ball, which means the function does NOT produce unique results. This is also referred as the Pigeonhole Principle.

no, hashes do not have to be unique – to the contrary, because of pigeon hole principle it's trivial to prove that there are (essentially) infinitely many inputs that provide the same hash function output (because the lengths of input are unbounded while output is some relatively small size, like 32 bytes); what needs to be hard to do is finding either two that have the same hash or finding a different input that has the same hash value

As a cryptographer, I take some issue with your explanation. What you describe, is not in fact a cryptographic hash function (see wikipedia on this one), as its definition replaces collision resistance with your more specific 'uniqueness' attribute. This change forces a hash function to have quite a large output (as data gets large), instead of the -- commonly used -- fixed (small) length. Many appications rely on the fact that a hash, even of arbitrarily large data, is small.

This change is not cruicial to the usage with stored passwords, but furthers the confusion about what cryptographic primitives can provide which security goals. Your definition blurs the lines between hash and encryption, as both are now bijective and 'hide' their content.

08:43 Hank says "a hash function needs to be unique, meaning you can never get the same string of gibberish from two different passwords". But that's not actually true, is it. If the hash is 64 characters and the passwords were of arbitrary , then by definition there are more combinations of passwords than hashes: they will sometimes produce the same result. We use MD5 hashes on computer files to check for a change. If the MD5 hash is 64 characters long, the file could be kilobytes, megabytes, or even terabytes+ long. It's not only possible but certain that two entirely different files could result in the same hash. It's just highly unlikely that they will.

Uniqueness isn't really a password hash requirement.  It's like door keys, there are many more door knobs than possible keys.  Your door key opens another door, but you don't know which one.  A password hash works the same way, so your long password can be fit into the 256 or 512 bits of SHA-3.

A cryptographic hash function doesn’t need to be unique, it needs to have a large enough number of solutions that the chance of collision is very low. MD5 results in a 128bit number meaning that there are 3.4x10^39 possible results.

Where did you get that a good hash is unique? That’s impossible, unless your output is allowed to be arbitrarily large.

You were close in an intuitive sense though; what you really want is for it to be infeasible to find two inputs that have the same hash values. (This allows for the possibility of fixed size outputs, which is what most real world applications use.) So yeah, if you’re allowed large outputs what you said is fine, but that’s never practical.

Quick nitpick, the hashed passwords shouldn't always be repeatable. Each user should get a salt, or a (ideally) random piece of information added to the hash. If the hash is strictly repeatable hackers can brute force commonly used passwords such as 1234 or the like and begin to learn how the hash works.

"[A hash is] this weird gibberish that only the computer can then understand" is probably an unclear description. A computer can "understand" the hash no better than a person, otherwise it would be decipherable. It's essentially gibberish to the computer too. The computer stores the hash instead of the password precisely because a potentially hackable computer should not retain knowledge that it can use to reproduce the password.

Around the 3:00 mark i know what those marathon runners where thinking (other than "why the hell did i sign up for this!"). They are wanting to move forward, as quickly as they can, as soon as they can. They also don't want to hit the person in front of them hard, don't want to be disqualified (or break social norms) by pushing their way around, through, or over other runners, and don't want to fall to the ground and be trampled. Equations and fluid dynamics aren't needed to predict what will happen, as row two has to wait for row one to move and then react, row three has to wait for row one to move and row two to react and then react themselves, row four has to wait for row one to move, row two to react then move, row three to react to row two, then react and move themselves, and so on. The further back you go the longer it will take for the runner's wishes to move forward to be realized with their other wants being met ( being fair, not hurt, etc). This would, and does happen, regardless if the start had a funnelling aspect to it or not, it just adds time for the whole process to be completed and adds an element of confusion in the minds of the runners as to how best to meet their contradicting goals (go fast vs don't die), again adding more time. Don't use hash functions to store passwords or similar. Use key derivation functions. Even something as modern as SHA-512 is insufficient. The cryptographic hash functions are designed to verify data integrity and authenticity, not to store passwords securely. When you want to check authenticity or both integrity and authenticity the you use an HMAC algorithm.

Database leaks are common and many don't store passwords properly. It's common that they either use plain text or hashing. Stay up-to-date and use the right algorithm for the job. Using hash functions for storing passwords is like using a sledge hammer on screws, it's a very bad of idea.

Hashing for data integrity, keyed hashing (HMAC) for integrity+authenticity and key derivation functions (KDF) for storing secrets in a one-way fashion.

Cryptographic hashing functions don't actually have to produce unique results for every input, but rather just to make it incredibly unlikely for two inputs to produce the same output (called a collision). Generally a hash function will always output a value of the same size, but can take inputs of any size (even ones larger than the output). Since the input space is much larger (in many cases, technically infinite) than the output, there have to be collisions, but in a good cryptographic hashing function they are incredibly rare and entirely unpredictable. So for example an input that collides with ILoveSciShow could very well be hundreds of characters of total gibberish and an attacker would have a harder time discovering that than the intended password, thanks to the one-way feature of the hashing function.

8:47 Actually, it's usually not the case that hashing algorithms are truly unique, because it's logically impossible if the created hash has a predefined size.
Take MD5 (as example ... not to store your passwords, please). it produces 128 bit hashes. The values you can generate with 128 bit are limited, the strings you can input into the algorithm are unlimited though. Since a set containing every possible md5 output is a subset of every possible md5 input, it can't be unique.

The uniqueness of those functions is rather an extreme unlikeliness than an actual uniqueness.

An uncle of mine explained electrical flow as being like water  when I was a kid(35 years ago). I've applied fluid dynamics to many different practical problems since and it has been very useful in helping me find real world solutions.
Cats
One word: Communism!

Hm, well, the first two examples were not toooo surprising, both being extensive variables. And independent on what those extensive variables are, under certain conditions, they act like fluids. A much more surprising example, where equations of fluid dynamics describe something else, are electromagnetic field equations. Especially, cause here, there is no extensive variable that flows!
And the last example is not really specific to fluids. The hashes are simply highly nonlinear equations and thus show similarities to other phenomena described by nonlinear equations. The pouring in of milk into coffee is simply one example for that. You could as well use a ball bouncing off a curved surface, this has the same similarities to hashes.
So this is just a "cute" episode of SciShow, but not one of the best and probably to be explained by the time of the year ;)

Careful, mentioning Bitcoin in a video might get you a strike on YouTube nowadays.

Otherwise, this was really interesting. I'm guessing that there are quantum phenomena that play a role at the very lowest levels in fluid dynamics. Even given the exact same initial conditions, you might not get the same result. But the non-linear relationship between initial conditions and end result is definitely reminiscent of cryptographics hash functions.
